parks.fullName: Abraham Lincoln Birthplace National Historical Park
parks.description: For over a century people from around the world have come to rural Central Kentucky to honor the humble beginnings of our 16th president, Abraham Lincoln. His early life on Kentucky's frontier shaped his character and prepared him to lead the nation through Civil War. The country's first memorial to Lincoln, built with donations from young and old, enshrines the symbolic birthplace cabin.

entranceFees.description: There is no fee associated with visiting either unit of the park.
entranceFees.title: Fee Free Park

parks.directionsInfo: The Birthplace Unit of the park is located approximately 2 miles south of the town of Hodgenville on U.S. Highway 31E South. The Boyhood Home Unit at Knob Creek is located approximately 10 miles northeast of the Birthplace Unit of the park.

operatingHours.description:
The Memorial Building is open 9:00 am - 4:30 pm eastern time with a limited viewing area.  The Visitor Center and grounds of the Birthplace Unit are open 9:00 am - 5:00 pm eastern time with one-way traffic flow and social distancing.


The Boyhood Home Unit at Knob Creek grounds are open daily sunup to sundown. The buildings are closed for the winter.
operatingHours.name: Abraham Lincoln Birthplace National Historical Park

images.title: The Memorial Building with fall colors
images.altText: The Memorial Building surrounded by fall colors
images.caption: Over 200,000 people a year come to walk up the steps of the Memorial Building to visit the site where Abraham Lincoln was born

images.title: The Memorial Building
images.altText: The first memorial erected to honor Abraham Lincoln
images.caption: The Memorial Building constructed on the traditional site of the birth of Abraham Lincoln.

images.title: The Symbolic Birth Cabin of Abraham Lincoln
images.altText: The symbolic birth cabin on the traditional site of the birth of Abraham Lincoln.
images.caption: The symbolic birth cabin of Abraham Lincoln.

images.title: Statue of the Lincoln Family in the Visitor Center
images.altText: Statue of the Lincoln family in the park's Visitor Center
images.caption: Visitors to the park can view the statue of the Lincoln family.

parks.weatherInfo: There are four distinct seasons in Central Kentucky. However, temperature and weather conditions can vary widely within those seasons. Spring and Fall are generally pleasant with frequent rain showers. Summer is usually hot and humid. Winter is moderately cold with mixed precipitation.
parks.name: Abraham Lincoln Birthplace

parks.description: Acadia National Park protects the natural beauty of the highest rocky headlands along the Atlantic coastline of the United States, an abundance of habitats, and a rich cultural heritage. At 3.5 million visits a year, it's one of the top 10 most-visited national parks in the United States. Visitors enjoy 27 miles of historic motor roads, 158 miles of hiking trails, and 45 miles of carriage roads.

entranceFees.description: Admits private, non-commercial vehicle (15 passenger capacity or less) and all occupants. Valid for 7 days. If a vehicle pass is purchased, no other pass is necessary.
entranceFees.title: Acadia Entrance Fee - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: Admits one or two passengers on a private, non-commercial motorcycle. Valid for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Acadia Entrance Fee - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: Admits one individual with no car (bicyclist, hiker, pedestrian). Youth 15 and under are admitted free of charge. Valid for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Acadia Entrance Fee - Per Person

entrancePasses.description: Valid for 12 months from purchase date. This pass provides access to Acadia National Park only. This pass admits the pass holder and passengers in a non-commercial vehicle.
entrancePasses.title: Acadia Annual Pass

parks.directionsInfo: From Boston take I-95 north to Augusta, Maine, then Route 3 east to Ellsworth, and on to Mount Desert Island. For an alternate route, continue on I-95 north to Bangor, Maine, then take I-395 to U.S. Route 1A east to Ellsworth. In Ellsworth, take Route 3 to Mount Desert Island.

operatingHours.description: Acadia National Park is open year-round. Check our website for park facilities operating hours, such as Hulls Cove Visitor Center.
operatingHours.name: Acadia National Park

images.title: Acadia's rocky coastline
images.altText: Large puffy clouds dot a brilliant blue sky as wave crash against the rocky coastline of Acadia.
images.caption: Millions of people come to Acadia for our distinctive rocky coastline.

images.title: Heavy snow-laden trees
images.altText: Hiking tracks carved through three feet of snow wind through a heavy snow-laden forest.
images.caption: During the colder months snows transform our landscape into a winter wonderland.

images.title: Sunset atop Cadillac Mountain
images.altText: A brilliant sunset filled with hues of blue, red, orange, magenta, and purple highlight the sky.
images.caption: As the tallest point on the eastern seaboard Cadillac Mountain provides fantastic viewpoints.

images.title: Climbing The Precipice
images.altText: Two hikers ascend a sheer cliff trail by way of historic iron rung ladders.
images.caption: Whether it's a stroll along Ocean Path or a difficult ascent up The Precipice, there are hiking trails for everyone!

parks.weatherInfo: Located on Mount Desert Island in Maine, Acadia experiences all four seasons. Summer temperatures range from 45-90F (7-30C). Fall temperatures range from 30-70F (-1-21C). Typically the first frost is in mid-October and first snowfall begins in November and can continue through April with an average accumulation of 73 inches (185 cm). Winter temperatures range from 14-35F (-10 - 2C). Spring temperatures range from 30-70F (-1-21C).
parks.name: Acadia

parks.description: From the sweet little farm at the foot of Penn’s Hill to the gentleman’s country estate at Peace field, Adams National Historical Park is the story of “heroes, statesman, philosophers … and learned women” whose ideas and actions helped to transform thirteen disparate colonies into one united nation.

entranceFees.description:
2021 Update: Entrance Fees are waived for 2021.  As a result, America the Beautiful Passes are not currently available at Adams National Historical Park.

The entrance fee is for all visitors age 16 and older.  Children under 16 are free. Credit or Debit Card only.
entranceFees.title: Individual Entrance Fee - 2021 Update

parks.directionsInfo: Traveling on U.S. Interstate 93, take exit 7 - Route 3 South to Braintree and Cape Cod. Take the first exit off Route 3 south - exit 42 - and follow signs toward Quincy Center. Continue straight on Burgin Parkway through six traffic lights. At the seventh traffic light, turn right onto Dimmock Street. Follow Dimmock Street one block and turn right onto Hancock Street. The National Park Service Visitor Center, located at 1250 Hancock Street on your left. Validated parking is in the garage to the rear.

exceptions.name: Birthday of Martin Luther King, Jr.

operatingHours.description:
Presently the grounds are available to the public from dawn until dusk. Visit the Old House at 135 Adams Street and the birthplaces of John Adams and John Quincy Adams at 133 Franklin St. Street parking is available at both locations. House tours are finished for the season and expected to resume in May 2022. 

The Visitor Center in Quincy Center is open from Monday - Friday, 11am - 3pm. The LAZ garage for parking is accessed from Saville Ave. Parking validated for free.
operatingHours.name: Homes Closed, Grounds & Visitor Center Open

images.title: The John and John Quincy Adams Birthplaces
images.altText: The Birthplaces of Presidents John Adams (right) and John Quincy Adams (left)
images.caption: The Birthplaces of John and John Quincy Adams sit right next  to each other on Franklin Street.

images.title: The Birthplace of John Adams
images.altText: The Birthplace of John Adams
images.caption: The house where President John Adams was born in 1735.

images.title: The Birthplace of John Quincy Adams
images.altText: The Birthplace of John Quincy Adams
images.caption: The house where President John Quincy Adams was born in 1767.

images.title: Old House at Peace field
images.altText: A view of Old House at Peace field
images.caption: Old House at Peace field, where four generations of the Adams family lived from 1788 to 1927.

images.title: The Paneled Room
images.altText: The Paneled Room located inside Old House at Peace field.
images.caption: The Paneled Room greets everyone who enters Old House at Peace field.

images.title: The Stone Library
images.altText: The Stone Library located outside Old House at Peace field.
images.caption: The Stone Library houses up to 14,000 books belonging to the Adams family.

images.title: Inside the Stone Library
images.altText: Inside the Stone Library
images.caption: A view into the Stone Library

images.title: The Gardens Located at Old House at Peace field
images.altText: The gardens located at Old House at Peace field.
images.caption: The gardens located by Old House at Peace field bloom in every color you can imagine.

parks.weatherInfo: Be prepared for hot, humid weather. The historic homes are not air conditioned. While the visitor center remains open all year, the historic homes are closed from November 1 through April 30.
parks.name: Adams

parks.description: Alaska’s parks, forests, and refuges are rich and varied. The Alaska Public Lands Information Centers help visitors and residents to have meaningful, safe, enjoyable experiences on public lands, and encourages them to sustain the natural and cultural resources of Alaska. These centers provide trip-planning, interpretation, and education for all ages.

entranceFees.description: No entry fee to visit the visitors center
entranceFees.title: Free Admittance

parks.directionsInfo: Anchorage APLIC is located in downtown Anchorage on 4th Avenue, in the Federal Building. Fairbanks APLIC is located in downtown Fairbanks on the corner of Dunkel Street and Wendell Avenue, near the Chena River.

operatingHours.description:
Summer Hours: 9-5, Every Day, Late May to Mid September, Open Federal Holidays
Winter Hours: 10-5, Mon-Thur, closed for lunch 12-1, September to Early May, Closed Federal Holidays
operatingHours.name: Anchorage Hours

operatingHours.description:
Summer Hours: 8-6, Every Day, Memorial Day through Labor Day, Open Federal Holidays
Winter Hours: 8-5, Mon-Sat, Labor Day through Memorial Day, Closed Federal Holidays

101 Dunkel Street Suite 110
Fairbanks, AK 99701

Telephone: 907.459.3730
Fax: 907.459.3729
Email: fair_interpretation@nps.gov
operatingHours.name: Fairbanks Hours

images.title: Hikers on Angel Rocks
images.altText: Two Hikers stand on top of a very large granite boulder, looking out across the landscape
images.caption: Hikers on top of Angel Rocks near Fairbanks look out across the landscape of Chena River State Recreation Area

images.title: Anchorage APLIC
images.altText: Front of the Anchorage Federal Building, housing the Anchorage APLIC
images.caption: The Anchorage APLIC is located inside the Federal Building

images.title: Fairbanks APLIC
images.altText: Fairbanks Alaska Public Lands Information Center, located inside the Morris Thompson Cultural & Visi
images.caption: Fairbanks Alaska Public Lands Information Center, located inside the Morris Thompson Cultural & Visitors Center, in summer

parks.weatherInfo: Visitors center is located inside the Federal Building and weather conditions are seasonal conditions of the Anchorage area, outside the facility.
parks.name: Alaska Public Lands

parks.description: In the early 1900s, paleontologists unearthed the Age of Mammals when they found full skeletons of extinct Miocene mammals in the hills of Nebraska -- species previously only known through fragments. At the same time, an age of friendship began between rancher James Cook and Chief Red Cloud of the Lakota. These two unprecedented events are preserved and protected here... at Agate Fossil Beds.

entranceFees.description: There is no fee for the visitor center or trails at Agate Fossil Beds National Monument.
entranceFees.title: Admission is free.

parks.directionsInfo: From US 20: 22 miles south of Harrison, NE on State Hwy 29, then three miles east on River Road (paved) From US 26: 34 miles north of Mitchell, NE on State Hwy 29, then three miles east on River Road (paved). From State Hwy 71: 25 miles west on the unpaved portion of River Road.

operatingHours.description:
The park's two trails are open from dawn till dusk every day.

Visitor Center features Miocene Mammal fossils, a 12 minute movie, and the James H. Cook Collection,  a unique collection of American Indian artifacts that were gifts to James Cook and his family.
operatingHours.name: Trails

operatingHours.description: Summer hours to Sep 30: 9:00am to 5:00pm daily. Please note Agate Fossil Beds is in the Mountain Time Zone.
operatingHours.name: Visitor Center

images.title: Visitor Center on the Prairie
images.altText: The visitor center sits in the middle of mixed grass prairie.
images.caption: From the Fossil Hills Trail the Visitor Center is a ship in a sea of prairie grasses.

images.title: The Agate Fossil Hills and Tipis
images.altText: Tipis and Fossil Hills represent the two subjects that Agate Fossil Beds interprets.
images.caption: One of the first impressions that visitors have are the tipis and the Fossil Hills.

images.title: A July Storm Passes
images.altText: Thunderheads are common in July.
images.caption: Summer storms include thunderheads and lightning and can be exciting and dangerous.

images.title: Dinohyus in the Visitor Center Fossil Diorama
images.altText: The Dinohyus was a scavenger, nicknamed "Terrible Pig"
images.caption: Visitors stare in wonder at the huge head of the "apex" predator of the plains some 20 million years ago.

images.title: The James H. Cook collection
images.altText: This buckskin shirt decorated with quills was worn by Red Cloud.
images.caption: Visitors agree that this shirt decorated with quillwork and worn by Red Cloud of the Oglala Lakota is a priceless piece of history.

parks.weatherInfo: Summers can be very warm, high 90's to 100 with the frequent afternoon thunderstorms. Plan to hike early and come down from the higher points if storms threaten. Winter temperatures can dip as low as -20 with snow and wind. Heaviest snows can be expected in late Spring.
parks.name: Agate Fossil Beds

parks.description: The young child known as the "Plant Doctor" tended his secret garden while observing the day-to-day operations of a 19th century farm. Nature and nurture ultimately influenced George on his quest for education to becoming a renowned agricultural scientist, educator, and humanitarian.

entranceFees.description: The park is free of admission charge.
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fee

parks.directionsInfo: From Interstate 44, drive south on either: Interstate 49: Exit at Diamond (exit 35), then drive five miles east on highway V, and drive ¾ mile south on Carver Road to the park entrance. Highway 59: In Diamond, turn west on highway V and drive for 2 miles, and drive ¾ mile south on Carver Road to the park entrance.

operatingHours.description:
George Washington Carver National Monument is open 9:00 AM to 5:00 PM daily, except Thanksgiving Day, December 25, and January 1.  There is no park entrance fee.

We are working to increase access to the park visitor center in a phased approach. The George Washington Carver National Monument visitor center is open with limited capacity . The information desk, park store, main floor museum, multipurpose room, and restrooms will be open. The theater and upstairs discovery area will remain closed.
operatingHours.name: George Washington Carver National Monument

images.title: Statue of young George Washington Carver on the Carver trail
images.altText: Bronze status of young George Washington Carver atop a large boulder, on the Carver trail.
images.caption: "Boy Carver Statue," sculpted by Robert Amendola in 1960.

images.title: George Washington Carver NM Entrance
images.altText: An entrance sign to George Washington Carver National Monument with wildflower and plants.
images.caption: Entrance sign to George Washington Carver NM will wildflower and plants.

images.title: George Washington Carver NM Prairie
images.altText: Sunflowers in a prairie at George Washington Carver NM.
images.caption: Prairie at George Washington Carver NM with sunflowers.

images.title: George Washington Carver NM Science Classroom
images.altText: Park's science classroom with lab tables and wall exhibits on George Washington Carver.
images.caption: George Washington Carver NM science classroom modeled after one of the George Washington Carver's lab at Tuskegee Institute.

images.title: George Washington Carver Bust
images.altText: A cast concrete bust of George Washington Carver and prairie in the background.
images.caption: A cast concrete bust for George Washington Carver by Audrey Corwin, 1952.

parks.weatherInfo: George Washington Carver National Monument is located in southwestern Missouri just outside of Diamond and about 10 miles from Joplin. Summer temperatures generally range from 75-100 degrees with high humidity. Winter temperatures generally range from 0-50 degrees with periods of intermittent freezing.
parks.name: George Washington Carver

parks.description: The Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail is approximately 4,900 miles long, extending from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, to the mouth of the Columbia River, near present day Astoria, Oregon. It follows the historic outbound and inbound routes of the Lewis and Clark Expedition as well as the preparatory section from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania to Wood River, Illinois.

entranceFees.description: Lewis & Clark National Historic Trail Headquarters Visitor Center  in Omaha, NE does not charge an entrance fee, but some of our park partners do. Be sure to check with each visitor and interpretative center to find out their fees.
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fee

parks.directionsInfo: Lewis & Clark National Historic Trail Headquarters Visitor Center is located inside DOI, National Park Service, Interior Region 3,4,5 Office. We are right on the Missouri River next to the Bob Kerrey Pedestrian Bridge in downtown Omaha, NE.

operatingHours.description: Lewis and Clark NHT visitor center in Omaha, Neb is open.
operatingHours.name: Visitor Center Hours

images.title: Giant Springs
images.altText: Small waterfall with brown rocks and green moss
images.caption: Giant springs is a site along the Lewis and Clark National Historic Site located in Great Falls, Montana

images.title: Sunset at Missouri Headwaters State Park, Montana
images.altText: sun dips behind mountains. In the foreground and meandering river catches the light. Leafy trees sur
images.caption: Sunset over Missouri River headwaters

images.title: Biking the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail
images.altText: Cyclist biking dirt path along riverfront. Leafy trees and wetlands habitat in distance.
images.caption: Cyclist along the riverfront along the Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail

images.title: Beacon Rock
images.altText: Water in the foreground with large conical rock on shore
images.caption: Beacon Rock along the Columbia River in Washington.

images.title: Park overlooking Ohio River in Wheeling, West Virginia
images.altText: Interpretive sign overlooking park and river in the background
images.caption: Lewis and Clark interpretive sign overlooking park and the Ohio River

parks.weatherInfo: In winter, watch for ice on trails and sidewalks. In summer, make sure to drink plenty of water and wear sunscreen on hot days. Keep in mind the Trail covers 16 states, use www.weather.gov to look up the specific area you plan to visit.
parks.name: Lewis & Clark

parks.description: Wilson's Creek was the first major Civil War battle fought west of the Mississippi River, and the site of the death of Nathaniel Lyon, the first Union general killed in action. The costly Southern victory on August 10, 1861, focused national attention on the war in Missouri. Wilson’s Creek NB commemorates and interprets the battle within the context of the war in the Trans-Mississippi West.

entranceFees.description:
Individual entrance is anyone walking or bicycling into the park and would be subject to paying an individual entrance to the park. Receipt is good for 7 days at Wilson's Creek National Battlefield.























Entrance Fees Will Resume May 29th, 2021. When collected, fee is $10.00 for an adult walking or bicycling into the park. An adult is anyone 16 and older. Children 15 and under are free. Receipt is good for 7 days at Wilson’s Creek National Battlefield.
entranceFees.title: Individual entrance (walking or bicycling)

entranceFees.description: Vehicle entrance fee is $20.00 (covers everyone in a non-commercial vehicle). Receipt is good for 7 days at Wilson’s Creek National Battlefield.
entranceFees.title: Vehicle entrance (non-commercial)

entranceFees.description: Motorcycle entrance fee is $15.00 per motorcycle. Receipt is good for 7 days at Wilson’s Creek National Battlefield.
entranceFees.title: Motorcycle entrance

entrancePasses.description: A twelve-month site specific pass valid only at Wilson's Creek National Battlefield. Pass covers cardholder and any additional adults arriving in the cardholders non-commercial private vehicle. If walking or bicycling into the park the pass covers cardholder and 3 additional adults arriving in the same non commercial private vehicle as the cardholder. An adult is anyone 16 years of age or older. Free entrance for children 15 years of age or younger.
entrancePasses.title: Wilson's Creek Annual Pass

parks.directionsInfo: From I-44: exit at Exit 70 (Missouri Highway MM). Continue south to U.S. Highway 60. Proceed through the intersection. Continue 1/2 mile to Missouri Highway ZZ. Turn right on ZZ. Continue south to Farm Road 182 (Elm Street). Turn left; the entrance to the battlefield is on the right. From U.S. Highway 65 (south of Springfield): turn left (west) on Missouri Highway 14 at Ozark. Continue on Highway 14 to Missouri Highway ZZ. Follow ZZ north to Farm Road 182. Turn right; the entrance is on the right.

operatingHours.description: Tour road, battlefield, and trails are open during posted hours (changes by season). Tour Road opens at 7:00 am for walkers and bicycles only. Vehicle entrance begins at 8:00 am which requires a gate token issued inside the visitor center.  The visitor center and museum hours are 8:00 am to 5:00 pm daily, seven days a week.  The Library hours are 9:00 am to 12:00 pm and 1:00 pm to 4:00 pm Tuesday-Saturday, closed Sunday and Monday.
operatingHours.name: STANDARD HOURS (TOUR ROAD)

images.title: Moonlight Tour
images.altText: Men in reproduction uniforms talk around a campfire
images.caption: Living history volunteers act out a scene during the annual Moonlight Tours event

images.title: Edwards Cabin
images.altText: Women in reproduction historic dress sit and stand on porch of old cabin
images.caption: Living history volunteers give demonstration at the historic Edwards Cabin

images.title: Lyon Marker
images.altText: A stone marker with engraving sits in front of a wooden fence and trees
images.caption: The 1928 Lyon Marker commemorates General Nathaniel Lyon, the first Union general to die in the Civil War.

images.title: Henry Rifle
images.altText: The receiver of an 1864 rifle shows decorative engraving with the original owner's name
images.caption: A rare 1864 Henry repeating rifle from the park's museum collection belonged to Missouri Civil War veteran George W. Fulton

images.title: Tour Road
images.altText: A man and woman walk with their dog on a paved road edged by trees and fields
images.caption: Visitors enjoy an evening stroll on the Tour Road.

images.title: Wilson's Creek National Battlefield Visitor Center
images.altText: Front Entrance of Visitor Center and Arrowhead on sign reading "Wilson's Creek National Battlefield"
images.caption: Begin your visit at the newly remodeled Visitor Center at Wilson's Creek National Battlefield.

images.title: The Lyon Bed
images.altText: General Nathaniel Lyon killed at  The Battle of Wilson's Creek was placed on this bed. The Lyon Bed.
images.caption: The Bed where General Nathaniel Lyon is placed, after being fatally wounded on the Battlefield.

parks.weatherInfo: Summer months are frequently hot and humid, with occasional showers and thunderstorms. Winter months (especially January and February) are frequently cold, with occasional ice and light snow. Spring and fall months are generally pleasant, with occasional showers.
parks.name: Wilson's Creek

parks.description: The Gateway Arch reflects St. Louis' role in the Westward Expansion of the United States during the nineteenth century. The park is a memorial to Thomas Jefferson's role in opening the West, to the pioneers who helped shape its history, and to Dred Scott who sued for his freedom in the Old Courthouse.

entranceFees.description:
The entrance fee is $3.00 per person. Entry is free for children under 16 and America the Beautiful pass holders. The tram ride, movie and riverboat cruises are an additional fee for adults and children.
Admission to the Museum Under the Gateway Arch is free.
entranceFees.title: Gateway Arch Entrance Fee

parks.directionsInfo: For directions click on the provided link

exceptions.name: Winter Hours, from the day after Labor Day until Memorial Day

operatingHours.description: The Gateway Arch is open year-round, closed only on Thanksgiving, Christmas, and New Year’s Day. Summer Hours run the Saturday before Memorial Day through Labor Day weekend and are the primary vistor season, if you plan to visit outside of this time please see the exception below.
operatingHours.name: The Gateway Arch

operatingHours.description: The park grounds are open daily, year round.
operatingHours.name: Gateway Arch Grounds

operatingHours.description: The Old Courthouse is closed for renovations. The National Park Service (NPS) has announced the Old Courthouse at Gateway Arch National Park will undergo renovations beginning in late 2021. The renovations are part of the final component of the $380-million CityArchRiver project, which has resulted in the revitalization of the Gateway Arch park grounds, Arch Visitor Center and Museum at the Gateway Arch and is the largest public-private partnership in the history of the National Park Service.
operatingHours.name: Old Courthouse

addresses.line1: Fourth Street between Market and Chestnut streets

images.title: Cherry trees in bloom
images.altText: The Gateway Arch and Old Courthouse with a row of pink blooming cherry trees in front
images.caption: The blooming cherry trees in Kiener Plaza provide a wonderful foreground for the Gateway Arch and Old Courthouse in spring.

images.title: Reaching for the Clouds
images.altText: Arch and clouds
images.caption: Arch reaching toward the clouds.

images.title: The Gateway Arch reflected
images.altText: The Gateway Arch reflected in the waters of of the north pond
images.caption: A walk around the Gateway Arch grounds provide many chances to view the Arch from many different angles.

images.title: The Old Courthouse
images.altText: looking across the green lawn in Smith Square to the Old Courthouse
images.caption: The Old Courthouse

images.title: West Entrance to the Gateway Arch Visitor Center
images.altText: West Entrance to the Gateway Arch Visitor Center
images.caption: Welcome to the Gateway Arch

images.title: Gateway Arch
images.altText: Gateway Arch
images.caption: Over a million people visit the Gateway Arch each year.

images.title: Old Courthouse
images.altText: Dred and Harriet Scott statue in front of the columns of the Old Courthouse in the morning light

parks.name: Gateway Arch

parks.description: Dinosaurs once roamed here. Their fantastic remains are still visibly embedded in the rocks. Today, the mountains, desert, and untamed rivers flowing in deep canyons support an array of life. Petroglyphs hint at earlier cultures. Later, homesteaders and outlaws found refuge here. Whether your passion is science, adventure, history or scenery, Dinosaur offers much to explore.

entranceFees.description: Admits one private, non-commercial vehicle (14 passenger capacity or less) and all occupants.
entranceFees.title: Dinosaur Entrance Fee - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: Admits all occupants on a private, non-commercial motorcycle
entranceFees.title: Dinosaur Entrance Fee - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: Admits one individual with no car to the monument - typically used for bicyclists and walk-ins. Youth 15 and under are admitted free.
entranceFees.title: Dinosaur Entrance Fee - Per Person

entrancePasses.description:
Valid for 12 months from purchase date.
Admits the pass holder/s and passengers in a non-commercial vehicle(14 passenger capacity or less) to Dinosaur National Monument.
entrancePasses.title: Dinosaur Annual Pass

parks.directionsInfo: Dinosaur National Monument is located on the Colorado and Utah border with a parts of the monument in both states. Dinosaur fossils are not visible in the Colorado portion of the monument - only on the Utah side. The Quarry Visitor Center and Exhibit Hall (where you see the dinosaur fossils) are located approximately 7 miles north of Jensen, Utah.

operatingHours.description: The outdoor areas in the monument is open 24 hours per day. Facilities such as visitor centers and the Quarry Exhibit Hall have specific hours of operation. Visit the Operating Hours & Seasons page for more information on facility hours. Some areas of the monument may close in the winter due to snow.
operatingHours.name: Dinosaur National Monument Hours

images.title: Camarasaurus Skull
images.altText: the fossilized skull of camarasaurus dinosaur
images.caption: Over 1500 fossilized bones of various dinosaurs are still embedded in the cliff face including a skull and several neck vertebrae of a camarasaurus

images.title: Camarasaurus Hump Specimen
images.altText: Large bones resembling legs, ribs and the vertebrae of a neck embed grayish brown rock.
images.caption: Fossils from a camarasaurus dinosaur display the well articulated specimens still found in the rock in the Quarry Exhibit Hall.

images.title: Steamboat Rock and the Green River in Echo Park
images.altText: the rocky pinnacle of Steamboat Rock rises over the Green River
images.caption: Steamboat Rock rises above the Green River in Echo Park

images.title: McKee Springs Petroglyphs
images.altText: Fremont rock art at McKee Springs
images.caption: The Fremont people left petroglyphs on many of the rock cliffs within Dinosaur National Monument including those at McKee Springs

images.title: Mitten Park from Harpers Corner
images.altText: view of a river flowing through a deep canyon
images.caption: Hikers arriving at the end of the Harpers Corner Trail are rewarded with a view of the Mitten Park Fault, Green River and the Yampa River Canyons

images.title: Night Sky over Tent
images.altText: the star filled sky above a tent
images.caption: Dinosaur's dark skies provides dramatic views of the Milky Way Galaxy

images.title: Rocky Mountain Bighorns
images.altText: A bighorn sheep lamb stands in front of a bighorn ewe.
images.caption: Visitors to Dinosaur may also see its diversity of wildlife including Rocky Mountain bighorn sheep.

images.title: Floating Rapids
images.altText: A green rubber raft floats over a rapid on a brown colored river in front of multi-colored mountains
images.caption: Rapids like those in Split Mountain Canyon challenge and thrill rafters on the Green River.

parks.weatherInfo: Dinosaur's climate is semiarid with temperatures averaging between 0°F to 30°F in January and 50°F to 100°F in July. Extreme winter low temperatures may reach -40°F and summer highs can top 110°F. Elevations within the park vary between 4,700 and 9,000 feet. Winter snow may be heavy at higher elevations while only light to moderate snow is found at lower elevations. Summer thunderstorms may cause heavy downpours and localized flooding, but fail to dampen parched soils less than a mile away.
parks.name: Dinosaur

parks.fullName: Great Sand Dunes National Park & Preserve
parks.description: Open 24/7 year round! There are no limitations or reservations to visit, but there is currently limited capacity in the visitor center. The tallest dunes in North America are the centerpiece in a diverse landscape of grasslands, wetlands, forests, alpine lakes, and tundra. Stay on a moonless night to experience this International Dark Sky Park's starry skies!

emailAddresses.description: Email a ranger to get your questions answered.

entranceFees.description: Passenger vehicle with all occupants; fee valid for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Non-Commercial Vehicle and Occupants

entranceFees.description: Per passenger, 16 years and older in oversized vehicle, including 15 passenger vans, small buses, etc. Valid for 7 days. Passengers under 16 are free.
entranceFees.title: Oversized Vehicle, 15+ passengers, age 16+

entranceFees.description: One motorcycle and all its riders; valid for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Motorcycle and Riders

entrancePasses.description: Covers one family's entrance for 12 months from time of purchase. Valid for two adults with signatures plus others in vehicle.
entrancePasses.title: Great Sand Dunes Annual Family Pass

parks.directionsInfo: To access the main park area, including the Dunes Parking Lot, Visitor Center, and Pinon Flats Campground, take US 160 to CO 150 from the south, or CO 17 to Lane 6 to CO 150 from the west. The national park is at the north end of CO 150.

operatingHours.description: The park and preserve are open 24/7 all year
operatingHours.name: Great Sand Dunes National Park and Preserve

images.title: Dunes and Crestone Peaks at Sunset
images.altText: Grasslands, large dunes, and snow-capped peaks at sunset
images.caption: The view at the park entrance contrasts giant dunes and snow-capped mountains.

images.title: Girls Sand Sledding
images.altText: Girls Sand Sledding
images.caption: Rent specially designed sand sleds to slide on the dry sand.  Note: cardboard, snow sleds, saucers, and other items don't slide on dry sand.

images.title: Elk, Grasslands, Dunes, and Sangre de Cristo Mountains
images.altText: Elk, Grasslands, Dunes, and Sangre de Cristo Mountains
images.caption: Elk are sometimes seen by visitors along the park entrance road or County Lane 6, primarily fall through spring.

images.title: Lower Sand Creek Lake, Great Sand Dunes National Preserve
images.altText: Lower Sand Creek Lake, Great Sand Dunes National Preserve
images.caption: Spectacular alpine lakes are part of the backcountry of Great Sand Dunes National Preserve

images.title: Upper Sand Creek Basin, Great Sand Dunes National Preserve
images.altText: Upper Sand Creek Basin, Great Sand Dunes National Preserve
images.caption: Sand Creek Basin, part of Great Sand Dunes National Preserve, contains lush forests and alpine lakes.

images.title: Fall Colors Along Mosca Creek, Great Sand Dunes National Park
images.altText: Fall Colors Along Mosca Creek, Great Sand Dunes National Park
images.caption: Fall is a pretty time to visit the park, with great colors and generally nice weather.

images.title: Gold Cottonwoods, Dunes, and Cleveland Peak
images.altText: Gold cottonwood trees, large dunes, a silver cloud, and snow-capped mountain
images.caption: Experiencing Great Sand Dunes in the quieter seasons of fall and winter can be a rewarding experience.

images.title: Girl Floating Medano Creek
images.altText: A teen girl sits on a floatation device
images.caption: Visitors can float Medano Creek's waves during late spring peak flow, in years of good snowpack

parks.weatherInfo: Temperatures are relatively cool all year, thanks to the park and preserve's high elevation. Conditions are most often calm, but winds can arise, especially in spring and during storm fronts. Daytime temperatures feel warmer here year round due to intense high-altitude sunlight, and a scorching mid-day summer sand surface. Plan to explore the dunes morning or evening during summer. Nights are cool in summer, and frigid in winter. Visit the Great Sand Dunes website for the most accurate weather forecasts.
parks.name: Great Sand Dunes

parks.description: For over 700 years, the Ancestral Pueblo people built thriving communities on the mesas and in the cliffs of Mesa Verde. Today, the park protects the rich cultural heritage of 26 tribes and offers visitors a spectacular window into the past. This World Heritage Site and International Dark Sky Park is home to over a thousand species, including several that live nowhere else on earth.

entranceFees.description:
This is a per-vehicle entrance fee for the summer season (May 1 to October 31, 2020). It is valid for seven days from the day of purchase.

Please note that we offer fee waivers for qualified education groups. Visit http://www.nps.gov/meve/learn/education/feewaiver_info.htm to learn more.

This is a per-person (bicyclist and individual) entrance fee for fall/winter/spring (January 2 to April 30, 2020 and November 1 to December 31, 2020). It is valid for seven days from the day of purchase.

Please note that we offer fee waivers for qualified education groups. Visit http://www.nps.gov/meve/learn/education/feewaiver_info.htm to learn more.

entrancePasses.description: The annual pass provides entrance into Mesa Verde National Park for a year, beginning from the date of sale. It covers the entrance fee for the pass holder and anyone in his/her vehicle.
entrancePasses.title: Mesa Verde Annual Pass

parks.directionsInfo: Mesa Verde National Park is in Southwestern Colorado. The park entrance is along Highway 160, between the towns of of Cortez and Mancos, Colorado. (10 miles east of Cortez; 9 miles west of Mancos; and about 35 miles west of Durango, Colorado.) Once you enter the park, the first view of a cliff dwelling is 21 miles (approximately 45 minutes) along a steep, narrow, and winding road.

exceptions.name: New Years Day - The park is open but all facilities are closed.
Thanksgiving Day - The park is open but all facilities are closed.
Christmas Day - The park is open but all facilities are closed.

operatingHours.description: The park is open, but services are limited. For more information on services, please visit https://www.nps.gov/meve/planyourvisit/ops_updates_covid19.htm.
operatingHours.name: Mesa Verde National Park Hours

images.title: Cliff Palace
images.altText: Large cliff dwelling in cliff alcove
images.caption: Cliff Palace, Mesa Verde's Largest Cliff Dwelling

images.title: Step House
images.altText: Park visitors visiting a cliff dwelling
images.caption: Visitors enjoying Step House, on Wetherill Mesa

images.title: Balcony House
images.altText: A cliff dwelling within a cliff alcove seen from across a canyon
images.caption: View of Balcony House from the Soda Canyon Overlook

images.title: Square Tower House
images.altText: View of cliff dwelling from above a canyon
images.caption: Square Tower House from overlook along the Mesa Top Loop

images.title: View of Spruce Tree House
images.altText: View of cliff dwelling from across canyon
images.caption: Spruce Tree House

images.title: Spruce Tree House
images.altText: Within a cliff dwelling
images.caption: Spruce Tree House, Mesa Verde's third largest and best preserved cliff dwelling

images.title: Mesa Verde Visitor and Research Center
images.altText: Visitor center entrance with sculpture of Ancestral Pueblo climber in front plaza.
images.caption: Stop by the Mesa Verde Visitor & Research Center at the park entrance where park staff will help you plan your visit.

parks.weatherInfo: Spring: Temps range from 40 F to 70 F, but snowstorms can occur as late as May. Summer: Temps can reach well into the 90s F. Thunderstorms are common in July and August. Be prepared to bring and DRINK plenty of water. Fall: Temps can range from 50 F to 75 F. Snowstorms can occur as early as October. Winter: Temps can range from the teens to low 30s F. Icy roads are common. Snow tires, all-wheel drive, or chains, may be required. Be prepared with water, snacks, and layers of warm clothing.
parks.name: Mesa Verde
